channel.title: OnLive
channel.description:
This looks pretty gurrrrd! http://kotaku.com/5181625/see-onlive-in-action
Sure, there are some serious question marks over things like latency, but come on. It'd be a mean, mean person who wasn't even a little excited by OnLive's potential to change gaming. Cloud computing, transcending the need for a particular console? Playable on your TV, your PC, or even your Mac? It's ground-breaking stuff. Provided it works. Speaking of how it works, here are a couple of announcement interview clips, showing exactly that. How it works. Or at least hopes to work.
They're claiming they can stream any game, over an internet connection on pretty much any basic computer that are sold today - running at 720p@60fps. Depending on the price, i'm pretty sure i'll be picking this up - my PC isn't the greatest but can play almost all the games released now at reasonable settings, however - the thing that attracts me to it is that they'll be doing a mini-console for it, which works in the same way except you plug it into the TV - it has its own bluetooth controllers that actually look pretty good. So yeah, i'm pretty excited about this!

item.title: OnLive
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Play in SD then, he said there was an SD version too

This looks pretty awesome, I can’t wait until it comes to England in like 30 years.

item.title: OnLive
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

Does this mean, you are basically renting out a top-end pc from OnLive’s mini farm.
You still cant play good games on absolute crap pcs because you still need to be able to stream HD footage, which even my computer struggles to do

Read full topic

item.title: OnLive
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

No, this would harm microsoft’s xbox more than anything. Most of their big exclusive games on the xbox all go to the PC, this will means people could get much better versions on the PC at a cheaper price, so that narrows down the potential audience for the xbox.

Read full topic

item.description:

item.title: OnLive
item.dc:creator: @lawl lawl
item.description:
@lawl wrote:

what about single player games, what if you are on the road and dont have access to internets? you would still want to play single player games but if you also wanted to play it on onlive when you are home you would have to buy it twice
(edit: i am refering to games like gmod that you could play online as well as single player)

they say you can take your laptop to school and play from there but most of the time you wont have access to unfiltered internet from school etc.

Read full topic

item.title: OnLive
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

This device wouldn’t take the whole game market, however - the technology behind it potentially could.

Read full topic

item.title: OnLive
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

This would definately not take the whole game-market. People will always want to buy new computer hardware and games.

item.title: OnLive
item.dc:creator: @xEnt xEnt
item.description:
@xEnt wrote:

sounds good if they can back it up.

I personally don’t believe it can stream that fast to not even notice a difference (or for it to be actually playable) for that matter.

What about australia? theres no way in hell we could use this with our bandwidth limits. Also

This may work with < 10 ping/latency
